Award.AwardTitle: Event Triggered Unknown Networked Control System Design by using Adaptive Dynamic Programming

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop new universal control designs for Network Control Systems (NCS) such as the new distributed control systems needed for the smart grid and modern automotive systems. Unlike many traditional NCS systems, these will be designed from the start so as to maximize performance over time, fully accounting for communication delays in networks and unexpected events, as well as nonlinearities, continuous random disturbances and other issues which this PI has addressed in the past. He intends to develop rigorous mathematical proofs that these new designs will always lead to stable operation. He will also maintain a pipeline to immediate practical applications, through his existing Industry-University Center on Intelligent Maintenance. The designs are intended to be general, learning-based and massively parallel, in a way which may also help us understand how mammal brains can perform tasks beyond the scope of more traditional types of design.

These designs will be an extension of work previously funded by NSF, described in the Handbook of RLADP, edited by Lewis and Liu. ADP, like linear programming, is a class of challenges, not just one specific method, though there are relations between the successful methods. ADP includes all the methods aimed at the general problem of multistage optimization in the face of nonlinearity and stochastic disturbance. In order to cope with general nonlinear tasks, this project will include neural networks which have been proved to be more effective as approximators of general nonlinear functions than more traditional systems. The chief novelty here is the ability to combine these capabilities with the presence of communication delays and random discrete events, which are an important practical issue in most NCS.

Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

Performance_Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many real-time systems such as smart grid, network manufacturing systems, automotive control systems are implemented as distributed control systems wherein the control loops are closed through a real-time communication network. Therefore they are referred to as Network Control Systems (NCS).  The interest for NCS is motivated by many benefits they offer as the ease of maintenance and installation, the large flexibility and the low cost. However, many theoretical issues such as the selection of transmission interval of the state and control vector and optimal controller design for NCS have to be investigated before the benefits can be harvested. On the other hand, in recent years, neural network (NN)-based dynamic programming (NDP) is being investigated for the design of optimal/suboptimal controllers. The delays and packet losses in NCS can degrade the performance of control systems designed without taking into account the effects of these network imperfections and can even destabilize the NCS. Unfortunately, no work is currently being attempted to develop online event sampled robust controllers where network imperfections such as delays, packet losses and quantization errors can be considered along with the transmission of state and control vector. Existing adaptive dynamic programming (ADP)/NDP schemes render unsatisfactory performance in the presence of delays alone as shown in the preliminary effort.

For the past few years, the investigators and their students have developed a new framework for optimal controller design for such NCS without using iterative methodology that is quite common with existing mathods.  This novel fremwork allows the NCS to operate in a forward in time even under uncertainties resulting from network imperfections.  This framework is mathematically rigorous and offers a breakthorugh in the design of optimal control since the optimizarion is carried out in finite and infinite time. The control methodology can be implemented using outputs alone relaxing state measurements. This effort extends the optimal controller framework to incorporate event sampling, optimization and design of controllers for NCS.

As part of intellectual merit, the proposed research presented an opportunity to deal with a more powerful and unified paradigm of complex learning problems and envisions a brain-like controller. The approach taken here employs an adaptive estimator –based or a NN learning as a fundamental block within the proposed framework, to provide forward-in-time solutions to complex dynamic optimization problems for complex real-time application environments such as cyber-physical systems where network imperfections become part of the control loop.  Optimal control of NCS is the first step towards attaining such cyber-physical systems.  This research will advance the state of the art for optimal control by providing rigorous mathematical analysis, stability and performance guarantees in the presence of unknown system dynamics, disturbances, delays and packet losses for a class of nonlinear systems without using iterative approach.  Moreover, by applying the theoretical results to an emerging vehicle systems, smart grid etc, NDP will gain wider acceptance. 

As part of  broader impact, this research leads to significant advances in the development of advanced optimal control schemes for unknown linear and nonlinear NCS with applications to smart grid, which has a direct impact on delivering the energy security for the clean environment and network enabled manufacturing.  Within the controls research community, this work will push the advances of learning systems to the next level and will inspire more theoretical results coupled with practical implementations. The proposed work utilized several important dissemination channels, including software, material for courses, special sessions, and journals and conference publications.   A book has been edited and international collaborations pursued in this area from rseearchers in India resulted in additional publication and exchange of students.


Last Modified: 02/04/2020
Modified by: Jagannathan Sarangapani
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Many real-time systems such as smart grid, network manufacturing systems, automotive control systems are implemented as distributed control systems wherein the control loops are closed through a real-time communication network. Therefore they are referred to as Network Control Systems (NCS). The interest for NCS is motivated by many benefits they offer as the ease of maintenance and installation, the large flexibility and the low cost. However, many theoretical issues such as the selection of transmission interval of the state and control vector and optimal controller design for NCS have to be investigated before the benefits can be harvested. On the other hand, in recent years, neural network (NN)-based dynamic programming (NDP) is being investigated for the design of optimal/suboptimal controllers. The delays and packet losses in NCS can degrade the performance of control systems designed without taking into account the effects of these network imperfections and can even destabilize the NCS. Unfortunately, no work is currently being attempted to develop online event sampled robust controllers where network imperfections such as delays, packet losses and quantization errors can be considered along with the transmission of state and control vector. Existing adaptive dynamic programming (ADP)/NDP schemes render unsatisfactory performance in the presence of delays alone as shown in the preliminary effort. For the past few years, the investigators and their students have developed a new framework for optimal controller design for such NCS without using iterative methodology that is quite common with existing mathods. This novel fremwork allows the NCS to operate in a forward in time even under uncertainties resulting from network imperfections. This framework is mathematically rigorous and offers a breakthorugh in the design of optimal control since the optimizarion is carried out in finite and infinite time. The control methodology can be implemented using outputs alone relaxing state measurements. This effort extends the optimal controller framework to incorporate event sampling, optimization and design of controllers for NCS. As part of intellectual merit, the proposed research presented an opportunity to deal with a more powerful and unified paradigm of complex learning problems and envisions a brain-like controller. The approach taken here employs an adaptive estimator –based or a NN learning as a fundamental block within the proposed framework, to provide forward-in-time solutions to complex dynamic optimization problems for complex real-time application environments such as cyber-physical systems where network imperfections become part of the control loop. Optimal control of NCS is the first step towards attaining such cyber-physical systems. This research will advance the state of the art for optimal control by providing rigorous mathematical analysis, stability and performance guarantees in the presence of unknown system dynamics, disturbances, delays and packet losses for a class of nonlinear systems without using iterative approach. Moreover, by applying the theoretical results to an emerging vehicle systems, smart grid etc, NDP will gain wider acceptance. As part of broader impact, this research leads to significant advances in the development of advanced optimal control schemes for unknown linear and nonlinear NCS with applications to smart grid, which has a direct impact on delivering the energy security for the clean environment and network enabled manufacturing. Within the controls research community, this work will push the advances of learning systems to the next level and will inspire more theoretical results coupled with practical implementations. The proposed work utilized several important dissemination channels, including software, material for courses, special sessions, and journals and conference publications. A book has been edited and international collaborations pursued in this area from rseearchers in India resulted in additional publication and exchange of students.
